Abstract: The proceedings contain 20 papers. The topics discussed include: strong quantum correlations in four wave mixing in 85Rb vapor; spontaneous symmetry breaking as a resource for noncritically squeezed light; cavity nano-optomechanics: a nanomechanical system in a high finesse optical cavity; adiabatic passage methods in cooling trapped molecular ions; phase transition and storage of quantum optical information in spatially periodical atomic structure; ultralong photon storage using an optical locking; wave function formalism in quantum optics and generalized Huygens-Fresnel principle for N-photon states: derivation and applications; design of a tunable single photon interferometer based on modal engineered tapered optical fibers; frequency-modulation high-precision spectroscopy of coherent dark resonances; uncertainty, entropy, and non-Gaussianity for mixed states; and quantum water-filling solution for the capacity of Gaussian information channels.

Authors: Rakich P.T., Wang Z., Popović M.A.
Title: Engineering optical forces in waveguides and cavities based on optical response
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albquerque, NM 87185-1082, United States; Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rakich, P.T., Sandia National Laboratories, PO Box 5800, Albquerque, NM 87185-1082, United States; Wang, Z., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Popović, M.A., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: We present a new treatment of optical forces, revealing that the forces in virtually all optomechanically variable systems can be computed exactly and simply from only the optical phase and amplitude response of the system. This treatment, termed the response theory of optical forces (or RTOF), provides conceptual clarity to the essential physics of optomechanical systems, which computationally intensive Maxwell stress-tensor analyses leave obscured, enabling the construction simple models with which optical forces and trapping potentials can be synthesized based on the optical response of optomechanical systems. A theory of optical forces, based on the optical response of systems, is advantageous since the phase and amplitude response of virtually any optomechanical system (involving waveguides, ring resonators or photonic crystals) can be derived, with relative ease, through well-established analytical theories. In contrast, conventional Maxwell stress tensor methods require the computation of complex 3-dimensional electromagnetic field distributions; making a theory for the synthesis of optical forces exceedingly difficult. Through numerous examples, we illustrate that the optical forces generated in complex waveguide and microcavity systems can be computed exactly through use of analytical scattering-matrix methods. When compared with Maxwell stress-tensor methods of force computation, perfect agreement is found. © 2010 Copyright SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering.
Author Keywords: Gradient forces; Microcavity; Optical forces; Optomechanics; Waveguide
Index Keywords: 3-dimensional; Amplitude response; Analytical theory; Complex waveguides; Electromagnetic field distribution; Gradient force; Gradient forces; Maxwell stress; Maxwell stress tensor method; Optical force; Optical phase; Optical response; Opto-mechanics; Optomechanical systems; Response theory; Ring resonator; Scattering matrices; Simple model; Tensor method; Trapping potential; Variable systems; Electromagnetic field theory; Laser resonators; Maxwell equations; Microcavities; Photonic crystals; Resonators; Synthesis (chemical); Tensors; Waveguides

Authors: Arasa J., Oteo E., Blanco P., Royo S., Cifuentes A.
Title: Development of a compact tool for sealing the compensator group in final stages of alignment
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: CD6, Technical University of Catalonia, Rambla Sant Nebridi 10, Terrassa 08222, Spain; SnellOptics, Prat de la Riba, 35 local 3, Interior, Terrassa 08222, Spain; Servicevision, C/ Rios Rosas 20, Cornella de Llobregat 08940, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Arasa, J., CD6, Technical University of Catalonia, Rambla Sant Nebridi 10, Terrassa 08222, Spain; Oteo, E., SnellOptics, Prat de la Riba, 35 local 3, Interior, Terrassa 08222, Spain; Blanco, P., SnellOptics, Prat de la Riba, 35 local 3, Interior, Terrassa 08222, Spain; Royo, S., CD6, Technical University of Catalonia, Rambla Sant Nebridi 10, Terrassa 08222, Spain; Cifuentes, A., Servicevision, C/ Rios Rosas 20, Cornella de Llobregat 08940, Spain
Abstract: A high-precision, low-cost tool for optimal alignment of a compensator group in anamorphic objectives is presented. The system provides highly accurate information by analyzing the axis and field PSFs in the focal plane of the optical system under test. The PSFs are provided by a bundle of 9 different pigtailed laser diodes placed in the object field, and they are recorded by a lensless 2/3" CCD camera. The comparison of the simulated and obtained PSFs allows determining the optical element introducing the differences so action may be taken precisely on that element. The system is especially useful in non-rotationally symmetrical systems, where errors in axis position result into asymmetries of the PSF images. The tool is used for precise alignment of the cylindrical lenses in the compensator group of an anamorphic objective prior to sealing. Results show the system is able to detect misalignments of 100μm and axis positioning errors of just 30arcsec using off-the-shelf components without the need of high-precision positioning equipment. © 2009 SPIE.
Author Keywords: Alignment; Anamorphic system; Image quality; Optical testing; Optomechanics; PSF

Authors: Kruzelecky R.V., Wong B., Zou J., Haddad E., Jamroz W., Sloan J., Poirier M.
Title: Miniature high-resolution Fabry-Perot guided-wave spectrometer for planetary atmospheric remote sensing
Affiliations: MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of Waterloo, 200 University Avenue West, Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1, Canada; Institut National d'Optique (INO), 2740 rue Einstein, Sainte Foy, QC G1P 4S4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kruzelecky, R.V., MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Wong, B., MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Zou, J., MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Haddad, E., MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Jamroz, W., MPB Communications Inc., 151 Hymus Blvd., Pointe Claire, QC H9R 1E9, Canada; Sloan, J., Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of Waterloo, 200 University Avenue West, Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1, Canada; Poirier, M., Institut National d'Optique (INO), 2740 rue Einstein, Sainte Foy, QC G1P 4S4, Canada
Abstract: Infrared (IR) remote sensing of planetary atmospheres typically requires spectral resolution below 0.1 nm to resolve the fine structure of the optical absorption characteristics of relevant gas-phase species and minimize interferences. This is currently accomplished using large bulk-optic Fourier transform infrared (FT IR) or dispersive spectrometers with complex optomechanics to provide the required spectral discrimination through the selection of a large optical path length. However, the resultant large mass and power requirements carry a high cost penalty and risk for spaceborne missions, requiring costly, large space platforms. This paper describes the breadboarding of an innovative spectrometer concept, the Fabry-Perot (FP) guided-wave integrated optical spectrometer (IOSPEC), which synergistically combines two mature technologies to provide a miniature spectrometer capable of broadband operation at high spectral resolution to below 0.03 nm full width half maximum (FWHM) with a net mass under 3 kg. A special, tailored tunable FP filter is employed to provide the high spectral discrimination, allowing a large spectrometer input aperture. This is matched with a high-performance guided-wave IR spectrometer based on MPB Communications Inc. patented IOSPEC technologies to simultaneously provide the measurement of 256-512 high-resolution spectral channels over a relatively broad spectral range. By tuning the FP filter, a continuum of spectral measurement points can be obtained with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) advantage of at least SQRT(256) over scanned spectrometer systems. The guided-wave optics integration provides robust, long-term optical alignment and minimizes the system mechanical complexity. The FP-IOSPEC spectrometer volume and mass minimization enable multiple spectrometers to be accommodated on a low-cost microsat, optimized for selected measurement tasks and views, thereby enabling significantly improved data acquisition for remote sensing and science while minimizing the mission cost. The application of this innovative technology to the requirements of the potential Miniature Earth Observation Satellite (MEOS) mission to study critical aspects of the carbon and hydrologic cycles associated with climate change is discussed. © 2009 CASI.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric remote sensing; Bread-boarding; Broad spectral; Broadband operation; Dispersive spectrometers; Earth observation satellites; Fabry-Perot; Fine structures; Fourier transform infrared; Full width half maximum; Gas-phase species; Guided wave optics; High costs; High resolution; High spectral resolution; Hydrologic cycles; Innovative technology; IR spectrometers; Mass minimization; Mechanical complexity; Miniature Spectrometer; Mission costs; Optical absorption; Optical alignments; Optical path lengths; Optical spectrometers; Opto-mechanics; Planetary atmosphere; Power requirement; Space-borne; Spectral channels; Spectral measurement; Climate change; Earth (planet); Fabry-Perot interferometers; Fourier transforms; Gas absorption; Guided electromagnetic wave propagation; Innovation; Optimization; Remote sensing; Signal to noise ratio; Space optics; Space platforms; Spectral resolution; Spectrometry; Spectrometers

The topics discussed include: vapor phase release of silicon nanostructures for optomechanics application; shallow fresnel lens fabrication using grey scale lithography made by high energy beam sensitive mask (HEBS) technology and reactive ion etching; an evaporative co-assembly method for highly-ordered inverse opal films; micro-lithographically patterned optical thin film coatings; metalo-dielectric 3D photonic crystals prepared by metalization of opticaly microfabricated polymeric templates; fabrication of large area woodpile structure in polymer; advances in diffractive nanophotonics enabled by commercial photoreduction lithography; fabrication of diffractive optics for dense optical interconnects in optical computing; Nanoskiving: a novel method for nanofabrication and its applications in nanophotonics; and fabrication of surface plasmon resonators by nanoskiving single-crystalline gold microplates.

Authors: Deotare P.B., Khan M., Loncar M.
Title: Vapor phase release of silicon nanostructures for optomechanics application
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deotare, P.B., School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Khan, M., School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Loncar, M., School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Abstract: Suspended silicon based nanostructures for optomechanic applications have been successfully fabricated using the Hydrofluoric acid (HF) vapor phase etching technique. In this paper, we demonstrate the fabrication of parallel silicon waveguides with a cross section of 250nm × 220nm, and photonic crystal nanobeam cavities with an air gap as small as 50nm between these released structures. The waveguides have been suspended over a distance of more than 75um. Stiction is a major issue for releasing structures with gaps in the order of tens of nanometers. At the same time, the process has to be gentle due to the small dimensions of the structures involved in the release process. HF vapor etching technique was successfully utilized to etch the 2um thick thermally grown sacrificial silicon o×ide layer. This process has an high yield as no liquid is in contact with the structures being released, thus eliminating any kind of liquid flow which typically proves to be a potential destruction source for such small structures. This HF vapor phase etching is a simple and controllable process which completely eliminates the requirement of any kind of sophisticated drying techniques needed with conventional wet etching. © 2009 SPIE.
Author Keywords: HF vapor; Optical resonators; Optomechanics; Photonic crystals; Sacrificial etching; Stiction; Waveguides
Index Keywords: Air gaps; Cross sections; Drying techniques; Etching techniques; HF vapor; Hf vapor etchings; High yields; Liquid flows; Optomechanics; Release process; Sacrificial etching; Silicon based nanostructures; Silicon nanostructures; Silicon waveguides; Vapor-phase; Crystal atomic structure; Fabrication; Hydrofluoric acid; Liquids; Nanostructures; Optical resonators; Photonics; Silicon on insulator technology; Stiction; Vapors; Waveguides; Wet etching; Photonic crystals

Authors: Harris J.G.E., Jayich A.M., Zwickl B.M., Yang C., Sankey J.C.
Title: Linear optical properties of a high-finesse cavity dispersively coupled to a micromechanical membrane
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States; Department of Applied Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, J.G.E., Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States, Department of Applied Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States; Jayich, A.M., Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States; Zwickl, B.M., Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States; Yang, C., Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States; Sankey, J.C., Department of Physics, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, United States
Abstract: We present measurements of an optomechanical system in which the mechanical element is inside the cavity, and couples dispersively to the intracavity field. This geometry makes it easier to simultaneously achieve high optical finesse and high mechanical quality factor in an optomechanical device. We measured the linear optical properties of a such a device in which the mechanical element is a 50 nm thick silicon nitride membrane. We find that the device's finesse, resonant transmission and resonant reflection can be explained with a simple model which allows us to extract the membrane's optical loss. Our results indicate that it should be possible to increase the finesse of these devices to 5×105 or higher.

Abstract: Space telescope designs driven by science goals such as the infrared observation of high-redshift galaxies and the infrared observation of objects that would otherwise be obscured by dust in the visible push the operating temperatures of the optics to cryogenic temperatures. Typical temperatures, 30 to 100 K are a challenging regime for actuators, but little information is available on the low-temperature performance of Piezo-electric actuator products currently on the market. Work is underway to measure actuator stroke and CTE, at low temperatures for typical PZTs, such as those available "off-the-shelf from P.I. and Thorlabs.

Authors: Palmer T.A., Alexay C.C.
Title: The trials (and tribulations) of light weight UAV optical system design
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: StingRay Optics, LLC, 310 Marlboro Street, Keene, NH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, T.A., StingRay Optics, LLC, 310 Marlboro Street, Keene, NH, United States; Alexay, C.C., StingRay Optics, LLC, 310 Marlboro Street, Keene, NH, United States
Abstract: Increasing demands for thermal imaging systems on unmanned aerial vehicles have led to a concentrated effort in the design and development of light weight infrared optical systems. Pre-engineered or commercially available infrared lens assemblies are typically unsuitable for such low mass and volume constrained applications. This paper will focus on the challenging aspects and design considerations employed to minimize the weight of the refractive elements as well as the associated opto-mechanical support housings. In particular, consideration will be directed towards the hurdles associated with the manufacture of systems intended to operate in this unique branch of surveillance optics.

Authors: Hatheway A.E.
Title: Optomechanics and the small-displacement domain
Affiliations: Alson E. Hatheway Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hatheway, A.E., Alson E. Hatheway Inc., United States
Abstract: The views of Alson E. Hatheway, president of Alson E. Halthway Inc., about the use of optical technologies in mechanical engineering, are discussed. Imaging systems, interferometers, telecom components and remote sensors features optical images, geometric rays and optical features described in the mathematics of geometric and physical optics. The equations of physical and geometric optics are increasingly being used in structural displacements. The deviation fraction can be applied to the expected errors in the change of the final image. A deep ultraviolet lithographic lens that suffers a thermo-optical instability needs a full opto-thermo-eleastic analysis, starting with Code V ray bundle plot. Finite element method can be effectively used to model the optical system characteristics to correct the mechanical design.

Authors: Hongyun Q., Yang L., Liqun S., Enyao Z., Qian T.
Title: CCD on-chip imaging for smart micro-object and fluorescence imaging system
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Hongyun, Q., State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Yang, L., State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Liqun, S., State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Enyao, Z., State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Qian, T., State Key Laboratory of Precision Measurement Technology and Instrument, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: The imaging method by simply putting the object directly on the surface of CCD or CMOS array chip is experimented. A 4.65*4.65μm pixel size 1024*768 CCD chip is used in the experiments. CCD's optic window is removed and surrounding lead on chip is covered with some glue to protect the CCD chip from damaged during the imaging operation. Light emitted or transmitted from object is gathered by the nearest one or several pixels. The comparative experiment shows, to compare the normal microscope imaging using the optic lens, Sharp image with no color shift, optic aberration and field distortion is achieved. To compare with a 4x N.A=0.1 lens at the same magnification, better light couple efficiency and simple optomechanics construction are achieved in our experiment system. As the key factors effecting the image PSF,MTF, resolution, contrast and couple efficiency, the object distance and illumination light path are analyzed and experimented. It shows this will be a potential ultra small size, high efficiency and low cost micro-object imaging and fluorescence imaging system for cell level biology photometry and imaging.
Author Keywords: CCD; Fluorescence; Imaging; Microscope; On-chip
Index Keywords: Charge coupled devices; Fluorescence; Lenses; Lighting; Microscopes; Photometry; Couple efficiency; Micro-object imaging; On-chip; Optomechanics; Imaging systems

Authors: Mancini D., Marra G., Cortecchia F., Sedmak G., Ferragina L., Fierro D., Caputi O., Mancini G.
Title: VST optomechanical technical specifications versus error budget
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Università di Trieste, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Valerio, 2, 34127 Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mancini, D., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Marra, G., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Cortecchia, F., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Sedmak, G., Università di Trieste, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Valerio, 2, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Ferragina, L., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Fierro, D., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Caputi, O., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy; Mancini, G., INAF, Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Via Moiariello 16, 80131, Napoli, Italy
Abstract: This paper concerns optomechanics tolerances specifications for VST telescope. It shows the strategy of tolerances definition for optomechanical systems. These prescriptions are the baseline for development and tests of VST telescope optomechanic components. The telescope is provided with an active optics control system, so some tolerances may be relaxed, respect to passive systems designs since they can be actively compensated. Gravitational and thermal deformations have been also considered. The design error budget strategy is described. This budget will be upgraded with the achieved budget including measured errors in order to compare them with the prescriptions. The Manufacturing, mounting and alignment tolerances have been evaluated within the whole telescope image quality error budget, in terms of rms spot radius. Since the telescope is seeing limited, effects of atmospheric seeing have also been considered in the error budget in terms of CIR. Do to its large field of view (1 degree square), the VST optical design (optomechanics tolerances included) is the first source of error if compared to a classical telescope design that has a small field of view. The overall optical quality depends also on telescope configuration (ADC and one-lens corrector or two-lens corrector configuration) and on observational zenith angle (0 ÷50°).
Author Keywords: CIR; Error budget; Optomechanics tolerances; Performance
Index Keywords: Deformation; Gravitation; Mechanics; Optics; Telescopes; CIR; Error budget; Optomechanics tolerances; Error analysis

Authors: Mosebach H., Schmidt E., Camus F.
Title: The ALADIN Transmit-Receive Optics (TRO) for the space-borne ADM aeolus wind lidar mission
Source title: International Astronautical Federation - 55th International Astronautical Congress 2004
Affiliations: Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany; EADS Astrium, Toulouse, France
Authors with affiliations: Mosebach, H., Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany; Schmidt, E., Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany; Camus, F., EADS Astrium, Toulouse, France
Abstract: This paper describes the design of the so-called Transmit-Receive Optics (TRO) for the Aladin lidar instrument on the future ADM Aeolus weather satellite. The TRO as the central optical unit of the Aladin instrument feeds the optical signals from the laser source to the emitting/receiving telescope, and vice versa, the received back scattered signals from the telescope to the spectrometers for Doppler shift evaluation. Additionally, a calibration branch is supported, which bypasses the telescope (from the laser to the spectrometers) and aims at levelling out the received signals in terms of wavelength and signal height changes due to wavelength and intensity variations of the laser. The TRO makes use of refractive optics (lenses) to a high extend taking advantage of the fact, that the spectral range of the Aladin instrument is narrow (centred at 354.8 nm). The opto-mechanical concept of the TRO features afocal optical groups, which are connected by parallel beams. Extreme requirements have been defined for the TRC on the end-to-end transmission (>= 73%) with an associated effective bandwidth of less than 1 nm over the 200-1100 nm spectral range. A solution to these stringent requirements is addressed in this paper. A further feature of the TRO are two so-called aberration generators on the emitting and calibration branch, with which an artificial astigmatism can be realised for eye safety reasons. A three lens configuration has been designed for the aberration genertor. Its effect on astigmatism is presented. This article also addresses the effort on stray light suppression, which is of high importance for the TRO. The qualification of optical coatings, the integration and test philosophy for the TRO concludes this paper.
Author Keywords: Aeolus satellite; Aladin instrument; Lidar; Optical design; Optomechanics
Index Keywords: Laser applications; Optical design; Optical signal processing; Transceivers; Weather satellites; Aeolus satellite; Aladin instrument; Optomechanics; Optical radar

Abstract: This paper describes the preliminary optomechanical design and analysis of the Gemini Adaptive Optics Bench being built by EOS Technologies, Inc. The overall optical arrangement is described, the optical tolerances are discussed, and an overview of the optomechanical packaging is provided. Authors: Graue R., Kampf D.
Title: Herschel PACS optomechanical system
Source title: International Astronautical Federation - 55th International Astronautical Congress 2004
Affiliations: Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Graue, R., Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany; Kampf, D., Kayser-Threde GmbH, Munich, Germany
Abstract: The Photoconductor Array Camera and Spectrometer (PACS) development, one of 3 cryogenic Infrared instruments of the Herschel Space Observatory, has nearly reached its final stage with the successful assembly and test campaign for the Cryo Qualification Model (COM). The paper will give an overview about the final optomechanical and thermal design of the flight unit and the achieved results wrt. the COM assembly and test campaign of the PACS Focal Plane Unit. Specific emphasis is given to several innovative technical approaches. The specific design and verification of cryogenic Ge:Ga detectors distribution board electronics based on rigid flex multilayer bookbinder technology. The manufacturing techniques of the lightweight all aluminum system and the alignment and optomechanical stability verification under cryogenic conditions is outlined. The already completed qualification program of a specially developed multilayer IR Black Paint "KT72" with outstanding IR-absorption features providing a very effective straylight suppression will be highlighted. The final architecture of the very sophisticated, highly temperature stable calibration sources is reported.

Abstract: FINITO is the first generation VLTI fringe sensor, implemented by the European Southern Observatory and the Osservatorio Astronomico di Torino (INAF-OATo). The project is based on a previous prototype from the Observatoire de la Côte d'Azur (F), completely redesigned accordingly to current VLTI specifications and requirements on optical layout, electronics and software. We describe the instrument concept, the expected performance and some details on the potential capability of VTLI complemented by FINITO.

Abstract: The German Instrument for Multi-channel Photometry and Astrometry (DIVA), dedicated to the German (DLR) small extraterrestrial satellite program, is intended a a kind of technology precursor mission to GAIA. As such, the phase B2 design activities wrt. the optomechanical and thermal design of the main instrument is described. Special emphasis is given to an exhausting, but very pragmatic thermomechanical and optical performance trade off between a cost effective athermal design concept, applying mirrors and an optical bench made from a specially treated isotropic aluminum alloy, and a thermally stable hybrid material concept based on a Carbon Fiber Reinforced Plastics (CFRP) sandwich structure and Zerodur mirrors.

Authors: López-Tarruella F.J.C., Ibarz J.M.F.
Title: The Global Model of the gran telescopio canarias
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: GTC Project, Instituto de Astrofis. de Canarias, 38200 La Laguna, (S/C Tenerife), Spain; IBERESPACIO Tecnologia Aerospacial, Glorieta de Quevedo 9, 28015 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: López-Tarruella, F.J.C., GTC Project, Instituto de Astrofis. de Canarias, 38200 La Laguna, (S/C Tenerife), Spain; Ibarz, J.M.F., IBERESPACIO Tecnologia Aerospacial, Glorieta de Quevedo 9, 28015 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: During the conceptual design of the GTC (Gran Telescopio Canarias) it was suggested to develop a Global Model of the behaviour of the GTC system to be used as a tool for the system engineering. This Global Model should be a dynamical simulation capable to predict the pointing, tracking, guiding and image quality of the GTC system in several simulation scenarios depending of the behavior of each subsystem. It was decided to develop the simulation in the Matlab/Simulink® enviroment. The kernel of the Global Model was a Simulink® model of the telescope mechanics. The model included the structural dynamics, control loops of the main axis (azimuth, elevation and rotators), and load models (wind, gravity, seism). Each component included error sources inherent to it (cogging and ripple on motors, encoding errors, bearing run-out, etc). The model permitted large rotations in elevation axis, which was necessary to test pointing performances. A specific simulation was developed within the project office for the analysis of the image quality of the optical system. It includes polishing defects of the optical surfaces (M1 segments, M2 and M3), low spatial frequency distortions of the optical surfaces (due to fabrication, gravity of instability) and misalignment between the primary mirror segments.
Author Keywords: Mechanics; Model; Optomechanics; Simulation; Structure
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Computer simulation; Errors; Finite element method; Image analysis; Optical systems; Sensors; Systems engineering; Gran telescope canarias (GTC); Optical telescopes

Title: Semi-kinematic rails for construction of optical test stands

Abstract: We describe a new mounting technique for rapid alignment using semi-kinematic (SK) rails. Features of the technique include structures for positioning lens elements, beam splitters, mirrors, and the like. The SK rails are less complicated to machine than traditional v- groove technology.

Authors: Jankovic Nebosja, Zhang Xiao-Mei, Basat Guri
Title: Prepare for inspection
Affiliations: Philips Semiconductors
Authors with affiliations: Jankovic, Nebosja, Philips Semiconductors; Zhang, Xiao-Mei, Philips Semiconductors; Basat, Guri, Philips Semiconductors
Abstract: A technique for the failure analysis in sub-micron processes in semiconductor industry was presented. Sagitta's automated sub-micron material polishing technology (SMPT) tool includes optomechanics and dedicated control and image processing. SMPT addresses the problems encountered during transmission electron microscopes (TEM) sample preparation by automating key process steps. TEM investigates interface layer morphology and defects implicated in yield problems. Milling technique offers alternative method for preparing samples of precision cross-sections used in TEMs.

Authors: Morris A., Bart S., Kane D., Lorenz G., Rabinovich V.
Title: A design flow for MOEMS
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morris, A., Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States; Bart, S., Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States; Kane, D., Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States; Lorenz, G., Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States; Rabinovich, V., Microcosm Technologies Inc, 4001 Weston Parkway, Cary NC 27606, United States
Abstract: As MOEMS transition from laboratory curiosities to production products inserted into telecommunication systems, a complete design flow is necessary for rapid product development to minimize time-to-market. We present a MOEMS design flow that provides efficient top-down design and accurate bottom-up verification. The detailed MOEMS device design is addressed along with an integrated capability for including other optical elements, opto-electronics, as well as drive and control electronics.

Authors: Miyazaki Daisuke, Ohno Yuji, Matsushita Kenji
Title: Alignment-free optical modules using solder-bump-bonding technique for free-space optical interconnections

Abstract: An optical packaging scheme based on alignment-free optical modules for free-space interconnection is presented. Authors: Bernier E., Popescu P., Mony M., Bisaillon E., Salzberg M., Kirk A.G., Plant D.V.
Title: 1.25 Gb/s transmitter for an adaptive redundant free-space optical interconnect
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bernier, E., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Popescu, P., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Mony, M., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Bisaillon, E., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Salzberg, M., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Kirk, A.G., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Plant, D.V., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: In order to provide a reliable optical link, the emitters and detectors within a free-space optical interconnect need to be aligned to each other within tight tolerances. Typical methods to achieve this alignment involve the use of precision optomechanics or active steering elements. An alternative approach to the alignment problem is to use spatial redundancy. One way to accomplish this is by increasing the number of possible optical links and using only a subset of those links to provide reliable high-speed channels. This paper presents the design and testing of a high speed transmitter chip developed for an adaptive redundant optical interconnect system. Optoelectronic design and device packaging will also be described.
Index Keywords: Electronics packaging; Microprocessor chips; Optical interconnects; Optical links; Semiconducting silicon; Semiconductor lasers; Transmitters; Vertical cavity surface emitting laser (VCSEL); Integrated optoelectronics

Authors: Wilkinson T.D., Crossland W.A.
Title: Optical recogniser based on FLC over silicon technology
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Cambridge Univ, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wilkinson, T.D., Cambridge Univ, Cambridge, United Kingdom; Crossland, W.A., Cambridge Univ, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: Recent developments have shown that it is possible to create an optical correlator, or recogniser, based on ferroelectric liquid crystal spatial light modulator technology. In this paper we present the expansion of this idea to include an in-house FLC over silicon SLM that allows a compact recogniser to be built. The basic architecture is the binary 1/f correlator built around a high-speed 320×240 pixel FLC over silicon SLM. Such an architecture can be built with low tolerance optomechanics to make a powerful yet robust optical recogniser. Initial result from this recogniser are presented in this paper along with a discussion of how this architecture can be used in more abstract recognition tasks such as motion estimation instead of the more traditional 'tank-in-the-bush' scenario.
Index Keywords: Cameras; Fourier transforms; Laser beams; Lenses; Liquid crystals; Optical correlation; Optical systems; Ferroelectric liquid crystals; Optical recogniser; Light modulation

Authors: Goodwill Dominic J., Hinton H.Scott
Title: Optical interconnect module extensible to 10,000 parallel channels for a smart-pixel optical backplane
Affiliations: Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goodwill, Dominic J., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States; Hinton, H.Scott, Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Abstract: A set of optics suitable for interconnecting and powering reflective hybrid-SEEDs in a free-space optical backplane is presented. Detailed design is conducted to demonstrate that the optics meet the constraints both of required performance, and of available fabrication. The design process shows that with given hybrid-SEED design rules a smart pixel density of 515/cm2 can be supported on a 1cm2 chip. By positioning the SEEDs on a slightly different grid spacing, this can be made to rise to 1125 smart pixels/cm2, that is 4500 windows/cm2. For a bit-rate of 200Mb/s, using ten such 1cm smart pixel chips per PCR results in a backplane with a bi-directional bisection bandwidth of 1.1 Tb/s.
Index Keywords: Calculations; CMOS integrated circuits; Hybrid integrated circuits; Integrated circuit manufacture; Integrated optics; Lenses; Light modulators; Optical design; Parallel processing systems; Performance; Printed circuit boards; Connection density; Differential optical input; Differential optical output; Diffractive optics; Gaussian beam; Hybrid SEED chip; Microlenses; Minilenses; Optomechanics; Smart pixel optical backplane; Optical interconnects

Authors: Barron Don R.
Title: Visualizing stray light
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Pilkington Optronics Ltd., Hayes Middx, UK, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Barron, Don R., Pilkington Optronics Ltd., Hayes Middx, UK, United Kingdom
Abstract: Stray light in optical systems is usually assessed by techniques which are essentially similar to those used in the design synthesis of the system. In general however the dimensionality of the actual build of the system is far higher than that of the design and the traditional 'ray tracing' assessment techniques can become unmanageable. Modern computer graphics software developed for CAD and the entertainment industry has been applied to this problem at Pilkington Optronics as part of the process of integrated optomechanical design. This paper describes the relevant features of the new software packages as applied to the analysis of stray light and presents some results from particular systems. A useful feature of the technique is the use of animation to reduce the dimensionality; these examples cannot be presented here in written form but some simplified examples are available on request on 3.5 inch diskette format.
Index Keywords: Optomechanics; Stray light; Animation; Computer aided design; Computer graphics; Visualization; Optical systems

Authors: Deslattes Richard D., Kessler Jr. E.G.
Title: Challenges to optomechanical design from x-ray interferometry and gamma-ray diffraction
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Natl. Inst. of Standards and, Technology, Rockville, MD, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deslattes, Richard D., Natl. Inst. of Standards and, Technology, Rockville, MD, USA, United States; Kessler Jr., E.G., Natl. Inst. of Standards and, Technology, Rockville, MD, USA, United States
Abstract: Optical determination of the spatial period of monocrystalline silicon is a first step toward such diverse goals as an atom-based replacement for the artifact kilogram, reckoning the masses of certain elementary particles, and measurement of the molar Planck constant. The needed measurements are realized through microfringe interferometric precision with a presently achievable accuracy of the order of 0.01 ppm. Application of such subnanometer standards to x-ray and particulary gamma-ray wavelength measurement requires accurate interferometric angle measurement nowadays effective at the sub-milli-arcsecond level. From results obtained to date, one can infer certain constraints on the future direction of subpicometer interferometry and sub-milli-arcsecond goniometry.
Index Keywords: Monocrystals; Optomechanics; Sub-milli-arcsecond goniometry; Subpicometer interferometry; Angle measurement; Atoms; Diffraction; Gamma rays; Interferometers; Optics; Precision engineering; Silicon; X ray apparatus

Authors: Ahmad Anees, Engelhaupt Darell E., Feng Chen, Li Ye
Title: Design and fabrication of low-cost x-ray mirrors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ahmad, Anees, Univ. of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, United States; Engelhaupt, Darell E., Univ. of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, United States; Feng, Chen, Univ. of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, United States; Li, Ye, Univ. of Alabama in Huntsville,, Huntsville, AL, USA, United States
Abstract: Traditional x-ray mirrors are quite expensive because of the fabrication cost involved in achieving a very high surface finish of the order of 15 angstrom or better. Currently, zerodur, and silicon carbide are commonly used as the substrate materials of choice for x-ray mirrors, and the required surface finish is achieved through traditional through traditional polishing methods, which are very expensive and time consuming. The cost of instruments for many new applications in the areas of biomedicine, nondestructive testing and space can be greatly reduced by using the replication methods for producing x-ray quality grazing-incidence type mirrors. This paper presents the optical and optomechanical design for a Wolter type I mirror and its mount, and the fabrication methods used to produce a low cost replicated nickel mirror. The finite element analysis (FEA) results for this mirror are also presented. The fabrication steps including the design and nickel and gold plating of the aluminum master mandrel used for the replication are also discussed. A surface finish of 10-15 angstrom was achieved for a mirror with a wall thickness of only 1 mm for such an electroformed mirror. These kind of replicated x-ray mirrors can result in a major saving in the weight as well as cost, while also making the resulting instruments much more compact and rugged.
Index Keywords: Optomechanics; X ray mirrors; Aluminum; Biomedical equipment; Cost effectiveness; Design; Electroforming; Fabrication; Finite element method; Gold plating; Mirrors; Nickel; Nondestructive examination; X ray apparatus

Authors: Plant David V., Hinton H.Scott
Title: Optical backplane demonstrators using micro-optics and smart pixel transceiver arrays
Source title: Conference Proceedings - International Phoenix Conference on Computers and Communications
Affiliations: McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Plant, David V., McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada; Hinton, H.Scott, McGill Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: We have demonstrated a representative portion of an optical backplane using FET-SEED smart pixels and free-space optics to interconnect Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) in a two board, unidirectional link configuration. 4×4 arrays of FET-SEED transceivers were designed, fabricated, and packaged at the PCB level. The optical interconnection was constructed using diffractive microoptics, and custom optomechanics. The system was operated in two modes, one showing high data throughput, 50 MBit/sec, and the other demonstrating large connection densities, 2222 channel/cm2.
Index Keywords: Cellular arrays; Communication channels (information theory); Electronics packaging; Integrated optoelectronics; Optical interconnects; Optics; Printed circuit boards; Printed circuit design; Printed circuit manufacture; Transceivers; Diffractive microoptics; Free space optics; Optical backplane demonstrators; Optomechanics; Smart pixel transceiver arrays; Optical communication equipment

Authors: McCormick F.B.
Title: Free-space optical switching and processing using FET-SEED smart pixels
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Naperville, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCormick, F.B., AT&T Bell Lab, Naperville, United States
Abstract: Smart pixel optoelectronic device arrays enable the interconnection and communication advantages of optics to complement the processing power of electronics in computing and switching applications. GaAs multiquantum well (MQW) FET-SEED smart pixels have been used in a 32 input, 16 output multistage switching fabric prototype using 5 stages of (2,1,1) node arrays (16 nodes/stage). Optimization of the initial system experiment has increased the fabric's bit rate from 50 Mb/s to 155 Mb/s per channel. These FET-SEED systems incorporate smart pixels using GaAs MQW modulators and detectors, computer generated holograms, 2-D fiber bundles, external cavity semiconductor lasers, high resolution bulk and microoptics, and custom optical bench optomechanics.
Index Keywords: Diffraction gratings; Errors; Light modulators; Optical fibers; Optics; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconductor lasers; Semiconductor quantum wells; Switching; Binary phase grating; Bit error rate; Optical switching; Smart pixels; Video codecs; Optoelectronic devices

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Current Developments in Optical Engineering IV
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The Proceedings of the Conference contains 27 papers representing the very latest developments in the optical and optical engineering subject areas not covered in the other conferences at the annual San Diego meeting. This Proceedings includes papers on basic optical design and engineering, e.g. the optomechanical laboratory hardware, its organization, terminology and devices; a precision dual positioning system; a Wollaston polarizer in imaging systems; a 20-element long focal length zoom lens; photolithographic lenses; a reflection microcirculation microscope. The session on waveguide and diffractive optics and microlithography comprises papers on the fabrication of ion-exchanged glass channel waveguides with etched and diffused grating taps; modular fiber optic assembly technique; forward photorefractive multibeam mixing in BaTiO3; correcting chromatic aberration in holographic optical systems. Miscellaneous topics include articles on optomechanical properties of PMMA and their applications in pressure sensors and on a Fabry-Perot tunable filter for visible and near IR using nematic liquid crystals.

Authors: Hatheway A.E.
Title: Optical analog analysis of optical fiber sensors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Alson E. Hatheway Inc, Pasadena, CA, 91101, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hatheway, A.E., Alson E. Hatheway Inc, Pasadena, CA, 91101, United States
Abstract: Optical fibers are popular devices for measuring a variety of physical phenomena; pressure, temperature, magnetic flux, etc. Analysis of optical fiber sensors has been limited to the classical Lame’ solution for conditions of plane strain. Finite element analysis can remove the plane strain limitation and allows the evaluation of realistic sensor configurations. This paper discusses the application of analog techniques to the modeling of wave propagation in a single mode quartz fiber using a finite element code. The results are compared to published data for pressure and temperature sensors. Precision Engineering and Optomechanics (1989). © 1989 SPIE.

Authors: Horchem S., Kohrman R.
Title: Optical alignment of a pupil imaging spectrometer
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: ITT Aerospace/Optical Division, Fort Wayne, IN, 46801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Horchem, S., ITT Aerospace/Optical Division, Fort Wayne, IN, 46801, United States; Kohrman, R., ITT Aerospace/Optical Division, Fort Wayne, IN, 46801, United States
Abstract: The optical alignment hardware and methods now in use for the GOES (Geostationary Operational Enviromental Satellite) Sounder optics are described. The alignment mechanisms and their mechanical and optical sensitivities are included. The alignment methods discussion includes a description of the prealignment testing and the optical measurements used for final instrument coregistration. Precision Engineering and Optomechanics (1989). © 1989 SPIE.

Authors: Robinson I.M.
Title: Optomechanics of polymer fibres and composite materials
Affiliations: QMC
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, I.M., QMC
Abstract: Raman spectroscopy was used to observe the strain behaviour for a series of poly(p-phenylene terephthalamide) (PpPTA) and substituted polydiacetylene (PDA-DCHD) fibres. The effect of resin shrinkage induced by high-temperature post curing of PDA-DCHD single-fibre composites was studied using a variety of techniques. A series of PDA-DCHD single-fibre composites was cured at room temperature and examined using resonance Raman spectroscopy and photoelasticity. A model for the distribution of stresses in a PDA-DCHD single-fibre composite was developed. A series of different low-volume-fraction PDA-DCHD and Kevlar 49/epoxy resin composites was also analysed using Raman spectroscopy.
Index Keywords: COMPOSITES; CURING; EMBEDDING MEDIUM; EPOXY RESINS; FIBRE REINFORCED COMPOSITES; FIBRES; HIGH TEMPERATURE; LIGHT MICROSCOPY; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MODELS (DESCRIPTIVE); PHOTOELASTICITY; POLY (DIACETYLENE); POLY (PHENYLENE PHTHALAMIDE); RAMAN SPECTROSCOPY; SHRINKAGE; STRAIN

Authors: Gijsbers T.G., Haisma J., Mesman W., Oomen J.M., Wijn J.C.
Title: ASPHERICS.
Affiliations: Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Gijsbers, T.G., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth; Haisma, J., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth; Mesman, W., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth; Oomen, J.M., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth; Wijn, J.C., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Abstract: Aspheric surfaces in optical systems can improve image correction, increase the numerical aperture and reduce the number of refracting surfaces required. The design work includes the calculation of aplanatic systems and designing for minimum wavefront errors and large field. Bi-aspheric objectives have been calculated for readout in LaserVision and Compact Disc, and also for writing the information onto the master discs for both systems. An aspheric system for projection television and a zoom lens have also been designed. The fabrication was 'optomechanical': the surfaces were turned and ground to an optical finish on COLATH. The optical elements produced are of diffraction-limited quality. The description of the fabrication includes quality of finish and optical aberrations, the alignment of the refracting surfaces and quality control. Inaccuracies of form of 0. 2 mu m and surface-roughness values of less than 5 nm have been achieved for small areas. Deterioration in quality due to machining marks is negligible. Measurement methods included interferometry (Twyman and Green), scattering measurements, stylus measurements and the determination of the spatial frequency response (MTF).
Index Keywords: ASPHERIC OPTICAL ELEMENTS; ASPHERIC SURFACES; OPTOMECHANICS; OPTICAL DEVICES

Authors: Shuttleworth R.A.
Title: Design and sensitivity of a photoconductive recording system applied to the Sucksmith ring balance
Affiliations: U. S. Army Signal Research and Development Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ
Authors with affiliations: Shuttleworth, R.A., U. S. Army Signal Research and Development Laboratory, Fort Monmouth, NJ
Abstract: This paper describes a photoconductive locator for continuous recording of physical displacement. The system is applied as an example to the optomechanics of the Sucksmith ring balance. It is shown that the sensitivity and accuracy are considerably higher than those obtained with optical instruments such as the traveling telemicroscope. Application to wave modulation is suggested. © 1962 The American Institute of Physics.
